title: Between 1 July 2017 and 1 July 2018, how many Model 3 cars will Tesla deliver to customers?
preds: Ex-post edit: we are under 29k: 28,386 reported: https://www.nasdaq.com/press-release/tesla-q2-2018-vehicle-production-and-deliveries-20180702-00512

Elon Musk drops hints about higher than expected (referring to the Goldman Sachs story) Q2 numbers [1] Whether he is referring to production, delivery, or even just the maximum weekly production rate of the factory (the "bust build" 5k target they've been talking about), nobody knows. [1] https://electrek.co/2018/06/27/elon-musk-tsla-tesla-model-3-delivery-numbers-internal-email/
Historical track record of over promising and under delivering
Goldman Sachs expects 22k deliveries in Q2: https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/18/06/11935867/goldman-sachs-tesla-could-hit-model-3-production-target

Crowdsourced deliveries are pointing to a slow June month. [1] The sheet's delivery estimate is likely to be an underestimate because Canadian deliveries might be under-reported.  [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vSkckurdmbXt5Bh4dVenUhsjoal1Y6qRIkFBG_tcOhTxGp6xUL5j8DqkMPY0K9TfOCDz83A_7HGcQCl/pubhtml?gid=570871356#

Reckoning:
. Total production of about 40 000 (36 354 with one week to go; 1 566 made in most recent week per Bloomberg)
. Sample deliveries via google ( @Emil ) reported as ~24 000 - but small sample size and Likely low 
. Including the ~1 000 already (mostly) delivered to Canadians (including in totals)
. Half of deliveries currently taking 3 weeks or longer (varies by geographical location)
. Through May 31, ~15 000 were delivered to customers BUT deliveries picked way up in June (given about double that number produced at May 31)
. In a Tesla first quarter earnings they reported 8 180 deliveries (again pace quickening)
. teslarati now reporting 83 000 likely deliveries in 2018 - given prod increases stand to reason would be well under half that (incl marginal 2017 production) by July 1 All this translates into something like 30 000 deliveries (out of 40 000 produced). Lots of guesswork so treat all of my info as questionably extrapolated!!!

Anyone know the details of the subsidies with the 200k units? Is it 'up to 200k' then no subsidy after that, or is it a one time annual payment and if they made/sold more than 200k they get $0? Maybe @Emil knows.  If it's a monthly payment deal up to 200k then it stops, then maybe Elon/Tesla won't mind going over it, but I'm guessing because it's a highly weighted factor, that it's an all or nothing deal.

On mon jun 18, Bloomberg  changed their model decreasing cars produced by 8% and decreasing the production rate significantly. This change to the forecasting model removes the possibility of the higher total. https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/
Agh this question man. Just throwing more in 36k
I still don't think delivery will take so long
Updating to deliveries not production numbers

https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/ 38k produced - 3k per week 2 weeks of production remaining - 44k ish on the lower end perhaps up to 5k (as elon pushes to meet the target) per week to get somewhere around 48k on the higher end

This crowdsourced spreadsheet, with an estimated 11% of customers reporting deliveries, shows weak numbers for scheduled deliveries in June posting toward <29k. [1] Alternatively, it could be that a lot fewer people reported their deliveries in June to the spreadsheet. However, the sample rate has been generally growing (probably as more people learn about the spreadsheet).  Another counterargument to the bearish forecast in the spreadsheet could be that its methodology for accounting for a possible ramp up toward the end of the quarter is too conservative. Yet another is that people are slow to report delivery dates or to update their data in the sheet once they get the date from Tesla. Still, this is not a good sign for deliveries. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vSkckurdmbXt5Bh4dVenUhsjoal1Y6qRIkFBG_tcOhTxGp6xUL5j8DqkMPY0K9TfOCDz83A_7HGcQCl/pubhtml?gid=570871356#
Per @Emil and others - difference between production and deliveries.

Data from three sources (InsideEV, CleanTechnica, which were linked in previous comments, and Tesla's own market share projections [1]) separately point to deliveries (which I am interpreting as synonymous to sales) as of June 1 equal to around 20-24k, suggesting a final number much lower than the consensus here, barring a very large rush of deliveries in June.  [1] https://twitter.com/Tesla/status/1004118655230078977

Bloomberg model now at about 37K, and takes some days for production to arrive to customers, so seems solidly within 36-43K group.  Also, stock price has been shooting up, probably an indication that recent production has been good.  InsideEV is reporting SALES, from what I see, which are entirely different from production or deliveries. Disclosure: I've been short TSLA shares and losing.

I am revising my assumption for the probability that Tesla withholds US deliveries in the name of the tax credit to 50%, which revises my decision tree analysis. As pointed out here [1] the Model 3's currently being delivered are the pricier ones that are going to the less price sensitive customers, making the expiry of the tax credit less of an issue. There might also be something to Elon's personality, who self-identifies as an engineer and technologist, that will make him scoff at the idea of caring so much about the wonky details of public policies so as to create a backlog of deliveries. Additionally, reliability of this source [2] notwithstanding, it makes it seem that Tesla is in fact not slowing down June deliveries. However, the numbers from [2] seem to run higher than Cleantechnica's delivery estimates for April and May [3]  [1] https://insideevs.com/teslas-200th-sale-will-they-or-wont-they/
[2] https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/12/tesla-shares-rise-after-analyst-raises-model-3-delivery-estimate-by-50-percent.html (HT @Hammer-Time)
[3] https://cleantechnica.com/2018/06/09/tesla-model-3-is-laps-ahead-of-other-us-plug-in-cars/

Not sure I believe these numbers but...as per others struggling with built vs deliveries.
https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/12/tesla-shares-rise-after-analyst-raises-model-3-delivery-estimate-by-50-percent.html

Based on Bloomberg's tracker I think we end up around 41,000 but I am leaving a a small margin for error because there is always room for strokes of luck and unexpected misfortune. https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/

According to Bloomberg's Tesla Model 3 tracker (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/), production is currently at 34k at around 2.5k per week. However, I budgeted about two weeks for deliveries, so I'm almost certain it'll be in the Between 36000 and 43000 inclusive bucket.

See comments from last week:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/739649 However...  I need to keep reminding myself of the reply I got from GJO: 
 (my last comment in this thread) https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/731366 So...  I have a sneaking suspicion that they are going to go by the total units produced since Bloomberg doesn't have any sort of tracker for __delivered__ cars.

Canada deliveries are bigger than I thought before. Note: InsideEV's numbers are only for the U.S. Deliveries in Canada started in May.  One spotted shipment in Toronto numbered at 1,000 in late May [1]. Another report mentions "hundreds of deliveries per day" at the end of May [2]. This suggests that deliveries there are an order of magnitude higher than what I assumed before.  To  summarize the main uncertainties are:
- Will Tesla withhold US deliveries to avoid exceeding the 200k threshold? (My guess: 80% chance)
- Is InsideEv correct about how close (5k) Tesla is to hitting that threshold? (My guess: 85% chance)
- How high will Canadian deliveries be for May and June?  On the last question, I divided it into three different categories - low, mid, and high - equal to <2.5k (i.e. 1k in May and 1.5k in June), 2.5k-6.5k, and >6.5k.    I used a decision tree and assigned probabilities to each uncertainty, calculated the final probabilities and then summed those outcomes that correspond to >29k and <29k. [1] https://electrek.co/2018/05/25/tesl-model-3-massive-shipment-canada-us-delays/
[2] https://electrek.co/2018/05/31/tesla-model-3-large-scale-deliveries-canada/

If InsideEV's numbers are correct, Tesla has sold 193k + 1900 Roadsters so far, making it only 5k away from the 200k threshold for federal tax credits [1]. Assuming Model S and X sales of about 3k per month, it doesn't leave much room for Model 3. Even if we assume restricted Model S and X sales (wouldn't be the first time Tesla is putting Model 3 first) we still don't have much room. InsideEV also has deliveries as of end of May for Model 3 at 20k. So, whether we end up in the <29k bin depends on two things:  - whether Tesla will optimize around the tax credit, which I think is not certain but likely.
- the accuracy of InsideEV's numbers. This pertains to their April and May numbers only as the rest has been confirmed and adjusted to match Tesla's numbers. It's difficult to systematically assess their past accuracy (for example they estimated Jan and Feb 2018 and then just filled in March based on whatever remained to match Tesla's numbers it seems) They did report that they have previously adjusted Model S quarterly numbers by ~5-10%. If I assume April and May numbers are actually 10% higher and 10k deliveries in June (consistent with recent production + a lag) then we barely get to 29k. [1] https://seekingalpha.com/article/4178823-tesla-hit-200k-june
The InsideEV data has made me question my bets and just putting 50-50 on lower buckets. Will adjust later.

According to insideev there are 20k delivered model 3 cars up to end of May and 193k all Tesla cars regardless model. I strongly believe they do not want to surpass 200k deliveries mark in June to be eligible for another quarter of 7500 tax credit. Only issue is that insideev data is covering only US market so some of model 3 can go to Canada, only foreign market where Tesla delivers model3,  and are not included in above numbers, hovewer tesla started to deliver model 3 to Canada only in mid of May and it is not huge market for ev cars yet therefore I do not believe it could be more than 1 or 2k .  Based on all above I strongly bet on below 29k with thin probability for higher bucket. I know that majority of forecasters here are using Bloomberg Tesla production tracker trying to figure out lag between production and deliveries but in my opinion insideev data will work better here as 1. It tracks deliveries not production. 2. There is no track record that Bloomberg model is really working and estimates production accurately.

Shifting due to low numbers from here [1]. Looks like production numbers from e.g. Bloomberg are running much higher than actual deliveries. There is also a significant chance the 200k threshold will lead Tesla to limit deliveries in June. [2]  [1] https://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/
[2] https://insideevs.com/top-6-automakers-200000-federal-tax-credit-limit/

Not sure why the WoC dropped, it's at ~33k now and doing ~4k a month. Maybe it'll do 5k this month.  Rumour that 6 planeloads of robots came in from Europe, but that would take days to install and it's too late. Not sure how much that increases production and if it's just for Model 3. Is a planeload a whole robot line or 3 lines in the 6 planes, or just one? I don't even know how many lines they have, is it one? Two? Three? So have they increased the line output by 100% or just 33%?  Not sure exactly what the reporting lag is, but will probably end up lower than I guesstimated around 37 to 40k

I'm shifting this radically downward.   @Emil, here is a more thorough walk through that I promised.   Bloombergs Tesla Tracker https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/ is showing 32,501 as of 0105, May 30th.   I know from experience with Audi that it takes 5 and 8 days to receive a car from the East Coast ON AN OPEN CARRIER once they leave the port.  Open carriers are the trucks you see with 8-10 cars stacked on the trailer, and because of which they have more stops to make, driver hours need to reset, etc., etc..  Enclosed carriers (Reliable Transport, United Transport) are the ones that look like moving vans but the trailers lack the multitude of doors on the side of the van, these only carry 2-4 because they do not have elevated tracks.  Fewer cars per transport, higher shipping costs, faster shipping, but more time to burn through the inventory.    Economically "open carriers" are dramatically more affordable and according to chatter many owners are receiving their cars this way.  They're also receiving their cars with other brands on the trailer, some of which are European brands...  This means that they are squeezing cars on the next available truck on the open market freight load boards like truckstop.com or DAT.com, which reverts back to the same issue you'd encounter with enclosed carriers - fewer cars going out per truck and a longer inventory burn rate.   So after all that, I got really curious I looked at (2018) satellite photos of the Fremont plant and counted a total of 688 vehicles waiting for shipping, with space for ~2000 more on the north end of the complex.  Their loading area (800 feet North by Northwest of the rail terminus) shows two very interesting things....  1: that only four trucks are being loaded and 2:  that one of them (in the middle of the three on the south end) is a "hot shot" which is basically a pickup truck with a trailer.  These are normally used for routes less than 800 miles and can carry 1-3 cars.  This shows that they are using non-dedicated trucking services; ie, they are desperate to get cars out.  It takes roughly 2 hours to load an auto carrier since each car is normally driven on by the truck driver, who also has to manipulate the hydraulics, chain down each car, secure the keys with the bill of lading, then go get the next car.  They have 6 marked loading spots with space for 12 (as we see one alone by itself north of the other three).  So at best, they can ship 384 per 8 hour shift...  But that's not how logistics works.  LOL.  From real world experience, assume there are no more than 3 trucks there at any given time, that it takes 3 hours to load, and that about 15 trucks per shift averaging 7 cars per truck.  These numbers are on par with their 30,000 deliveries in Q1.  https://www.statista.com/statistics/502208/tesla-quarterly-vehicle-deliveries/  3*15*7*90=28350.   We know that the X and S are also produced at the same facility so let's just assume that as much as half of the production and shipping is Model 3's, or 15000, or 5000 per month.   So....  In conclusion....   32,501 cars produced to date, with 5000 shipping per month with a maximum 10 day delivery period, or an average of 5 days (5/6th of a month) per car on each truck.  Add another ~4 days for a car to find a truck and you've got about 6-14 days from completion to delivery, or    5000 * 2/3 = 3333.   32,501 + 3333 = 35,834 To close to safely go all in, but I'll be circling back every few days to check production numbers and revise.

Tesla appear to be showing good progress on the production figures per week over Q1 figures but the timing for this question is critical, the potential late May shutdown should further increase the per week production that Elon Musk is targeting but will likely delay hitting the 50k figure for a couple of weeks. Equally there's a potential upset with introducing changes so soon after the last set of changes to production. either way the delivery lag from production means that the 50k delivery number (as distinct from production) will not be met until August at the earliest.
WoC0.53/0.41 Might just get to 42k or 43k.
Articles say Tesla has made 30k Model 3's so far
31 000 and almost 3 000/week. 5.5 weeks to go. Hmmmm, maybe they will hit 43 000?
If you can't even sell a car to Consumer Reports for testing, things are grim.  Or would be for any other company.   Stay tuned.

Five more weeks to go. Bloomberg estimates that Tesla has produced 28,449 Model 3 cars so far and is currently turning them out at a rate of 3,299 per week. That would bring us to 44,944 by the question deadline, but production may still be ramping up. Factory will be shut down 6 days in May, so subtract a week's production from that: https://cleantechnica.com/2018/05/16/tesla-fremont-factory-shutdown-in-late-may-to-focus-on-model-3-assembly-line-improvements/

Musk does it... again? https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/15/leaked-email-says-tesla-may-have-burst-of-model-3-production-this-week.html
Also: https://cleantechnica.com/2018/05/16/tesla-model-3-production-hits-4290-per-week-638-in-24-hours-rumor/ "A contributor over at the Tesla Motors Club forum by the name of Lbkmxp100d dropped some specific details about Tesla’s Model 3 production numbers on Monday that are allegedly straight from Tesla’s Fremont factory. Those numbers put Model 3 production for the 7 days prior at 4,290." Says Musk from Q1 Earnings Call: “The thing I’m most excited about is the rapid increase in output. We got just in the last 24 hours at the Gigafactory managed to achieve a sustained rate of over 3,000 packs per day – sorry, per week, and actually reached a peak hour with extrapolated outward would be a rate of about 5,000 cars per week." Going off Bloomberg's VERY helpful Model 3 Production Tracker (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/), we have around 27k right now, with just over six weeks left for the question. However, as @healther mentioned, it can take a while for them to be delivered. While there is no steadfast number, many people on the Tesla motor club forum say that theirs are delivered within 2-4 weeks of being ordered. Now, subtracting from those 6 weeks 2-4, 27k + 4.2k x 2-4  = 35k-44k. I put a 20% chance of More than 43,000 but less than 50,000 if Musk raises production substantially (as in closer to 5k, as he has talked about) and a 5% chance of 50,000 or more if he somehow magically boosts production way above that 4.2 mark (hey, it could happen. Especially with Elon Musk. You never know.). However, just in case the leak is false, I hade to put some safety margin in there with a 20% chance of More than 29,000 but less than 36,000. According to the Bloomberg tracker, production is currently at around 2.7k per week, so 27k + 2-4 (again, allowing for delivery) x 2.7 = 33k - 38k.

Right now they have about 30k produced vehicles and a production of 2.7k/week. With another 6 weeks to go we would end up at 48k, but there is a shutdown of 6-7 days scheduled and the question asks for deliveries not produced units. Counteracting these two reductions is the ramp up of the production rate itself. 
If we assume about a week for the delivery (they claim to be faster, but that is hard to verify) we have 25k delivered as of today, with 5 weeks (13k with current rate) left. This means we Tesla would end up with 38k, slightly above the 36k. There are 5k missing to the next bracket end (1-2 weeks of production, for current to target end of Q2 production rate). Ways to achieve 43k+: 
- ramp up production faster 
- reduce downtime
- reduce delivery time
The first is possible, but would need on the order of 1k/week additional vehicles with corresponds to an increase of 40%. While not unheard of, this seems optimistic. The second is unlikely as Tesla doesn't usually underestimate how long things take, so it might be 5 days instead of 6, but that ends up being maybe .5k vehicles. The last one is the big uncertainty. Ways to end up <36k:
- extend downtime of factory
- slow deliveries 
So far Tesla's problems originated in being too optimistic in how well their upgrades work, but they haven't screwed up something in an actually damaging way. I still give this a generous 15% because shit can happen. Once the downtime end of May is done I will revisit and probably end up completely in the 36-43k bracket.

Isn't it supposed to be over 29k now, so why are there bets in first bracket?  Anyhow, so nearly 20k a month potentially, so will hit right in the 40 to 50k mark in July depending on how many more shutdowns there are. Having a 6 to 7 day shutdown now. Which takes out anywhere from 3500 to 4000 or so, making it tricky to get the bracket right.

Tesla shutting down production for several days at end of May. Yes, will likely increase production but that’s about 2000 that need to make up...  
https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/15/tesla-is-shutting-down-model-3-production-for-six-more-days.html

Leaked email by Musk says it's "quite likely" they'll produce 500 cars per day this week [1]. If this happened, this would imply a slightly faster ramp than I expected. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/15/leaked-email-says-tesla-may-have-burst-of-model-3-production-this-week.html
The shipment as of CY1Q18 was still way below target.

It seems Tesla is on track for a ~40k cars production goal by end of Q3. Possibly even more. The challenge is the delivery. So I've readjusted my estimation to reflect the fact that it will most probably be a 36k-43k with a larger estimation for an overshoot (43k-50k) due to tge fact that it is amost certain that Tesla will make more then 36k by EOQ3. The question remains, will they have any more production difficulties and / or will they be able to deliver as many cars... ?!

29,929 made according to Bloomberg / 7 weeks left and currently making 2600/wk. If 2,600 /week continues that would be 44,000. 
Company news says they're targeting 5k/WK in June. That would be 51,000 assuming four weeks of 5K and three weeks of 2,600K. I'm not sure if deliveries equal cars made, so if I subtract a week, you get less than 50,000K. Given problems and prior misses I'm also skeptical of goal. However, production could ramp up more than 2,600 in last three weeks, if this goes to 3k for rest of of may and ramps up to 4k in June, still above 50K, so I still assgn meaningful odds to over 50k.
I think the weekly production downturn of the last three weeks is a blip and Tesla still ends up just over 43,000 but there is enough uncertainty that I am also uping the bucket just below that one.

Just shy of 25 000  with ~7 weeks to go. 2 000/week gets you to 39 000 (straight line). But production likely to increase (despite slight downturn). Don’t know if enough to get over 43 000. Musk needs to focus more on Tesla and less on Grimes (as interesting as she is)

Current data from https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/ Background info from https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/apr/17/tesla-halts-model-3-electric-car-production-improve-automation

Bloomberg suggest Tesla have produced 23,872 cars and have a current production rate of 1,561 per week and a maximum production rate of 2,665 per week (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/).  If the figures are correct Tesla will need to produce less than 653 cars per week to total less than 29,000.
It will need to produce an average of more than 1,544 (just under it's current best effort) to reach the 36,00 - 43,000 bracket.

Wow, production is nosediving.  I haven't looked in two weeks but now they're at 1533 per week:  https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/ Assuming that average holds steady for the next 8 weeks, that works out to 12,264 more cars...   They currently have 23,693 which means the total would be 35,957...  Talk about cutting it close.

1) Is 5,000 cars per week realistic? Volkswagen largest plant on Germany produces 19,000. Ford's largest plan in the US produces 8,853 and Honda (14 largest plant in US) produces 5,083 per week. Electric cars have less complicated engine parts than combustion so could be more quickly produced. 5000 is feasible.
2) Issues seem to be worker unrest, battery output and bottlenecks
3) Production stop in April and also February. Could this happen again?
4) 12,451 cars produced to Q1, 9,950 delivered. Assume 85% of produced cars are delivered
5) Bloomberg estimates 10,550 produced in April - high est 42k
6) Google crowdsource spreadsheet estimates 27,034 in Q2 low est 32k
7) Based on 2k rate continuing in April, and 1 missed week assume 6k in month, 3k pw in May, 4k pw in June total £39k delivered 
8) If delivery % higher could move into 43k-50k threshold
9) If Tesla target hit small chance of 50k +

Looks like the production rate in April was between 2k and 3k. https://cleantechnica.com/2018/05/01/tesla-model-3-production-deliveries-in-april-where-you-at/.  I continue to assume that the 5k burst built, even if it happens, will not be reflected in deliveries as it will happen toward the end of June and I assume deliveries will lag by 2 weeks based on the crowdsourced google sheet linked by Cleantechnica above. The 5k target is still useful as an optimistic estimate of the production rate for the last week of June (assuming they ramp up to demonstrate their production capabilities in the Q2 report). Since it's a burst built target, I assume the previous weeks will not see anything close to that, maybe 3-4k. So all in all, my base case projection is for a gradual ramp up toward 3-4k by the second to last week of June (including a few days of shutdown in May as indicated in the Q1 analyst call) and then a jump to ~5k.  Assuming Tesla delivers to customers whatever was produced two weeks prior (I discussed this more here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/725750), and that deliveries stood at 9,952 (as I explained here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/727552) as of end of Q1, we should be below 36k.

After crunching a lot of numbers, it looks to me like Tesla will not hit 200K us sales this quarter falling roughly 12k short.   Ergo I don't think incentives  will arbitrarily cap tesla sales.  Production supposedly 2237 per week last three weeks in april - but this was done by cannibalizing Model s/x sales.
Production shutdown last week in May scheduled.  I'm guessing a bump to 2500.  Updates as more info is known of course.
22450 to date and +2000/week (but increasing notwithstanding shutdowns). 9 weeks to go

Some useful research here: https://seekingalpha.com/article/4166809-unlocking-mystery-teslas-model-3-ramp?page=2 Summary: on the whole, I think the production-delivery lag might be significant in Q2, leading me to lower my forecast. To a large extent this depends on whether Tesla decides to optimize around the federal tax credit. See some other important considerations below.  Key points:  1) Tesla has an incentive to not hit a 200k sales threshold by end of Q2 so that it's customers can still use the federal tax credit throughout Q3. "The $7500 FIT credit will be phased out starting at the end of the quarter in which Tesla reaches 200,000 US sales."  "As of the end of Q2 [I assume author means Q1 here], US sales of Tesla Models S, X and 3 stood at 175,000 units. Assuming sales of 9,000 model S and X for Q2 leaves room for 16,000 Model 3 to be sold in the USA in Q2." This suggests that Tesla may employ strategies to delay deliveries in the US. This could mean delivering more cars in Canada. So one big implication from this is that the answer to this question may depend on how many deliveries are made to Canada specifically. It could also mean lengthening the gap between production and delivery, accumulating cars at the factory that Tesla then delivers to customers beginning of Q2. The model presented in the article does suggest a widening between production and deliveries in April. The author estimates "up to 5,000 cars held back for delivery in the first week of July to stay under the 200,000 FIT cap" There is a further question about the ability of Tesla's delivery/service infrastructure to keep up with higher production rates. Could that be another bottleneck? There is a comment below the article that talks about this. An overarching comment on this: Tesla is being largely evaluated on weekly production, not deliveries. So all of the recent news about new hires, 24/7 operation, optimizing the line, is probably focused on raising the production number to appease investors. As for deliveries, Tesla has latitude on how it decides to time them. 2) The author interprets, as I did, Musk's letter to mean there will be another shutdown in May. 3) Bringing on all the new hires will take time: "I am not expecting a major increase in production until the end of the quarter. Tesla will need 2,000 to 2,500 workers for a full third shift working a seven-day week. It will take at least six weeks to hire and train all those workers, so the third shift is unlikely to be added until the end of May at the earliest, most likely after the May shutdown." An additional problem is that Tesla might not have the tools needed to equip these workers. Ordering those will also take time.  The author implies that the production is a function mostly of the number of workers. I am not sure I agree with that. The shutdown in April will help Tesla optimize the line so output per worker should also be higher. 4) The author says 6,000 per week target "is intended to be only a *one day* “burst-build” rate for each department, it does not set a target of 6,000 per week for the whole operation. This suggests it's unlikely to see weekly numbers anywhere close to that.  5) The author estimates 20k deliveries in the US and Canada in Q2. This translates to 29,952 deliveries in total by July 1. This made me question whether Model 3's are being delivered anywhere outside the US and Canada. It seems the answer is 'no' from this article (https://electrek.co/2018/03/21/tesla-model-3-canada-price/). It will be important to watch whether Tesla opens up markets elsewhere. Given the short time frame that might be infeasible or immaterial for the question.

Revisiting my assumptions for the actual number of deliveries up to Q1 2018: Q3 2017: 222 (https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-q3-2017-report-pushes-model-3-production-ramp-to-2018/) Q4 2017: 1550 (http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=1053245) Q1 2018: 8,180 (http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=1062670) Total: 9,952.  When projecting from this number, it's important to account for the lag between production time and delivery time. I laid this out here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/725750

Right now we are up to just under 21,000 and Tesla is cranking out around 2,500 per week. At that rate Tesla can deliver 22,500 or so between now and July 1. That puts total deliveries at just over 43,000. However weekly production numbers are actually increasing a bit so I think Tesla probably ends up a bit higher in that range.

Unless something catastrophic happens, at 2K Model 3's delivered per week, in a quarter that's obviously over 26000 model 3's delivered. I have now gotten the chance to spend more time on my assumption for the lag between production and delivery.  Data sources: This website below links to a google spread sheet where customers have entered their delivery times. In total 780 customers (a decent sample size). The average time between when the customer received their VIN and delivery is *12.7 days*. (VIN registration is not the same as production though - as per Bloomberg: "Automakers register VINs in large batches that anticipate coming production, which means that numbers will be assigned before a new car starts its journey down the assembly line." https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/). So this number is an overestimate of the lag.  Additionally, the average is a little misleading for our purposes because the data is skewed to the right with a low number of customers experiencing very long delays. Both the median and the mode are 10 days. These are not working days but total days including weekends. So a bit less than 2 weeks on average. There is more analysis I wish I could do on this data but time constraints force me to leave it at that. Here is the link: https://forums.tesla.com/forum/forums/time-vinfinished-production-delivery-date-or-more-info Similarly, Tesla's Q1 announcement shows deliveries lag production by 1,586, which at their end-Q1 rate is about a week.  Future assumption:  The question still stands about the delivery lag for Q2. Especially - will the current efforts to ramp up at the Fremont factory do anything to lower this delivery lag? I actually doubt it. Musk's focus is on the production number. That's the metric he committed to so I assume that's what Wall Street is mostly looking at (though of course they cannot let deliveries sag too much). So I assume it will stay the same and it will be a little more than a week. Implications: This is an important assumption because any ramp ups toward the last week or two of Q2 (which I expect since Musk's 6k target and the official 5k target for end Q2 is a "burst-built" target as I mentioned earlier) will not be captured in the delivery data.  Based on this I find the >50k bin virtually impossible. It would require that Musk hits all of his targets and comments (which I elaborated on here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/724487) and that there is no more production pauses.
They may manufacture more, but they will try to push the 200k US sales limit into Q3, so there will be a lot of cars in transit to Canada or Europe (which takes much longer).

Production rampup, is being done quite drastically, the addition of a third shift, signals an aggressive move to obtain the 5K/week production goal, within Q2. While postponing the automation (and thus, margins) for a later stage... The question is what will be the average production rate from now to end of Q2. It is now at about 2.2k/week. How fast will Tesla reach the planned 5to6k/week? I suspect it will be about 4-4.5k/week on average in the comming 9 weeks undile Q2 end. Hence - 36,000 - 40,500 additional cars, on top of the 18.5k produced till now. I.e. around the 50k threshold, and I take the more carfull side of the threshold, to be on the safe side. P.s. I'm long TSLA.
Bah...  Go big or go home.

It is estimated that Tesla has produced 18,493 cars as of 4/20 and that they have a weekly production of 2,325 cars. Given that there are approximately 10 weeks remaining until 1 July 2018, it is safe to say that they will complete at least 43,000 cars - however, it is likely that production rates will continue to increase. Even a cumulative 10% increase in production per week would easily lead to 40,759 cars produced (or 39,247 if we put a cap of 5,000 cars per week as maximum). This would lead to the total number of cars being 59,252 (best case, 10% cumulative increase), 57,740 (second best, 10% with a cap of 5,000), or 41,743 (worst case, current total plus current rate times ten weeks).

This is a more fleshed out justification for my forecast. Please share any feedback! Here is the overarching point that I base my thinking on: extrapolating from past data (and more generally from our prior about Tesla that they always miss their targets) has become less useful for the purposes of this question after Musk's concerted push to alleviate Wall Street's concerns. The factory update this week, the move to 24/7 operation and the new hires that Musk wants to bring on will, I assume, significantly improve the factory's capacity. So I did a bottom-up estimation of total deliveries based on Musk's targets and comments. This is meant as an optimistic case that can help set the upper boundary. I also provide a few alternative models. Deliveries to date: There is some uncertainty, with Bloomberg data being updated retroactively, so I took this approach: the last confirmed number by Bloomberg was 12,452 deliveries by end of Q1 (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-tesla-tracker/). For the weekly deliveries since then I am using numbers reported by Musk himself in his company email from this week (https://electrek.co/2018/04/17/tesla-model-3-production-goal-6000-units-per-week/), which suggests 2,070 for the week of April 2 and 2,250 for the week of April 9. This means that as of the beginning of this week there were 16,772 deliveries. Week of April 16: 0 (assuming  plant stays closed) Next two weeks: assume plant comes back at the pre-closure rate of 2,250 and goes up in the following week to 3,000. This is trying to capture a ramp up to a number mentioned by Musk who wrote that the current closure should allow the factory to reach 3-4k weekly rate for May. First three weeks of May: 3,500 per week as the midpoint of Musk's estimate Last week of May: 0 (assuming plant closure alluded to by Musk's email which says "Another set of upgrades starting in late May should be enough to unlock production capacity of 6000 Model 3 vehicles per week by the end of June."  First three weeks of June: 3500. This is quite uncertain. It depends on how the plant ramps up production over time. An important consideration here is that the 6k target mentioned by Musk "by end of June" is a "burst-build" target. Here is the key quote: "By having a Model 3 subsystem burst-build requirement of 6k by the end of June, we will lay the groundwork for achieving a steady 6k/week across the whole Model 3 system a few months later." This implies that Musk doesn't believe this number is something they will be able to maintain so I assume that Tesla will not get close to that number on any consistent basis in Q2. Last week of June: 6000. (assuming they hit the target once to be able to report it in the quarterly report, and alleviate the concerns on Wall Street). This is an optimistic assumption. Musk said that the reason for the 6k target is to offer a margin of error and increase the likelihood they meet the 5k official target. Total by 1 July: 49k. Alternative assumptions (all assume a second closure the last week of May):  Alternative 1) if we instead assume the May-June rate is 3k as the lower bound of Musk's estimate and we assume they hit 5k end June instead of 6k, we get 45k. Alternative 2) what we may consider as a more pessimistic scenario is the factory coming back online at the pre-closure rate of 2250 and stays there until end of Q2. Result: 37k. Alternative 3) A very pessimistic case: Goldman Sachs assumed (before the closure, so this is now outdated but here is the reference from my earlier comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/721823) a rate of 1400. Result: 29k.  On the whole, I lean toward 43-50 and 36-43 because Tesla has a lot riding on this and is taking concerted action to at least get close to its 5k target, and my assumption is that it will be at least to some extent successful.

Confirmed numbers:
- produced until 1st April: 12.5k
- production rate beginning of April: 2k/week There are 13 weeks between 1st April and 1st July, assuming the 2k/week as a sustained rate this would leave us with 12.5k + 26k = 38.5k model 3 at the 1st of July. Facts that reduce the estimate:
- production has been halted for a week, leaving only 12 weeks (assuming everything goes as planned)
- 2k/week was probably achieved over only a short period of time
- numbers given here are production numbers, but question asks for deliveries Facts that increase the estimate:
- production actually ramps up (2.5k 2017Q4, 10k 2018Q1, same increase would mean 40k 2018Q2)
- Elon seems to have gotten that automatisation for automatisation sake does not necessarily mean higher output 40k/quarter corresponds to a sustained 3.1k/week, which is not too far away from the target 5k/week, so they probably won't be able to reach 40k in Q2. So if nothing bad happens they can produce 30k model 3 in Q2, which brings the total close to the 43k bracket. But due to the in-flight time and everything must work out requirements I'm giving it 3%.
So assuming they can start back at 2k/week after coming online again and they will linearly reach the 3k/week at the end of Q2, they would produce 25-30k. I actually think this is achievable, as it is well below the design capacity of the plant and they do seem to have  their logistic set up for that target. This would give a total of 40-45k cars produced but with a delivery time of maybe 7 days we end up at around 36k.  I give 10% chance of "something bad" happening and production essentially shutting down and distribute the rest with a slight preference to 36-43, but that might be wishful thinking on my part.

Initial stab based on previous work on the other version of this question: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/723992 An important factor here that as per Musk's company email from this week, the 5k-6k target the company has for the weekly rate by end Q2 is a "burst-build" target (https://electrek.co/2018/04/17/tesla-model-3-production-goal-6000-units-per-week/). This suggests that Tesla is hoping to demonstrate it can reach this target at some point in Q2 (and whether it even manages that is questionable), but not necessarily that it will maintain levels  anywhere close to this target.
